sen.j: 伏見天皇（ふしみてんのう、文永2年4月23日(1265年5月10日) - 文保元年9月3日(1317年10月8日)）は日本の第92代天皇（在位弘安10年10月21日(1287年11月27日) - 永仁6年7月22日(1298年8月30日)）。
sen.e: Emperor FUSHIMI (May 1st, 1265 - October 8th, 1317) was the 92nd Japanese Emperor. (his reign was November 27th, 1287 - August 30th, 1298.)
Emperor FUSHIMI (May 1st, 1265 - October 8th, 1317) was the 92nd Japanese Emperor. (his reign was November 27th, 1287 - August 30th, 1298.)
Emperor Fushimi (May 10, 1265 - October 8, 1317) was the ninety-second Japanese Emperor. (his reign was November 27, 1287 - August 30, 1298.)
sen.cmt: 日付表記修正統一のため the ninety-second Japanese Emperor に変更しました。

sen.j: 諱は熈仁（ひろひと）。
sen.e: His posthumous name was Hirohito,
sen.cmt: 諱→personal name [いみな] 諱 サンプル訳より
sen.e: His posthumous name was Hirohito,
His posthumous name was Hirohito,

sen.j: 書道の伏見院流の祖、京極派の有力歌人としても知られる。
sen.e: He was known as a founder of the Fushimi-in school of calligraphy, as well as know a talented poet in Kyogoku group.
He was known as a founder of the Fushimi-in school of calligraphy, as well as a talented poet in the Kyogoku group.
He was known as a founder of the Fushimi-in school of calligraphy, as well as a talented poet in the Kyogoku group.

sen.j: 後深草天皇の第二皇子。
sen.e: He was the second prince of Emperor GO-FUKAKUSA.
He was the second prince of Emperor GO-FUKAKUSA.
He was the second prince of Emperor Gofukakusa.

sen.j: 母は、左大臣洞院実雄の娘、玄輝門院・藤原愔子（愔＝りっしんべんに音）。
sen.e: His mother was Genki mon in, FUJIWARA no Inshi, who was a daughter of the Minister of the Lift, Saneo TOIN.
His mother was Genki mon in (FUJIWARA no Inshi), who was a daughter of the minister of the left, Saneo TOIN.
His mother was Genki mon in (FUJIWARA no Inshi), who was a daughter of the minister of the left, Saneo TOIN.

sen.j: 持明院統。
sen.e: Jimyo in Imperial line
sen.cmt: 持明院統→Jimyo in Imperial line [定訳不明]
sen.e: Jimyo in the imperial line
Jimyo-in imperial line
sen.cmt: It's difficult to say without seeing the text in context but this Japanese doesn't seem to appear on the Wikipedia page. That said, I think adding a hyphen between "Jimyo" and "in" makes it clear that this is the name of an imperial line.

tit.cmt: "Biography" -> "Brief Personal History" に変更しました。

sen.j: 持明院統の後深草天皇の働きかけにより、1275年、大覚寺統の後宇多天皇の皇太子になる。
sen.e: With the help of Emperor GO-FUKAKUSA of Jimyo in line, Emperor FUSHIMI became Crown Prince of Emperor GO-UDA from Daikakuji line in 1287.
sen.cmt: 大覚寺統→Daikaku ji Imperial line [定訳不明]
sen.e: With the help of Emperor Go-Fukakusa of Jimyo in line, Emperor Fushimi became the crown prince of Emperor Go-Uda from the Daikakuji line in 1287.
With the help of Emperor Gofukakusa of Jimyo in line, Emperor Fushimi became the crown prince of Emperor Gouda from the Daikakuji line in 1275.

sen.j: 1287年、後宇多天皇の譲位により即位。
sen.e: In 1287, he succeeded the Imperial Throne after Emperor GO-UDA abdicated.
In 1287 he succeeded the Imperial Throne following the abdication of Emperor Go-Uda.
In 1287 he succeeded the Imperial Throne following the abdication of Emperor Gouda.

sen.j: これ以後、大覚寺統と持明院統が交代で天皇を出す時代がしばらく続く事になる。
sen.e: After that both Daikaku ji line and Jimyo in line shared the succession the the Imperial Throne for a while.
Subsequently, both Daikaku ji line and Jimyo in line shared the succession to the Imperial Throne for a while.
Subsequently, both Daikaku ji line and Jimyo in line shared the succession to the Imperial Throne for a while.

sen.j: 後深草上皇は2年余りで院政を停止した為、以後天皇親政が続く。
sen.e: After Emperor GO-FUKAKUSA stopped ruling cloister government, there was a directly ruled government by the Emperor.
After Emperor Go-Fukakusa stopped ruling the cloister government, there was a government under the direct rule of the Emperor.
After Emperor Gofukakusa stopped ruling the cloister government in two years, there was a government under the direct rule of the Emperor.

sen.j: 1289年、自分の皇子である後伏見天皇を皇太子にしたため、大覚寺統との間の確執が強まる。
sen.e: In 1289, since Emperor FUSHIMI appointed his son, Emperor GO-FUSHIMI to become Crown Prince, it caused a feud between Daikaku ji line.
In 1289, because Emperor Fushimi had appointed his son, Emperor Go-Fushimi, to become the crown prince, it caused a feud with the Daikaku ji line.
In 1289, because Emperor Fushimi had appointed his son, Emperor Gofushimi, to become the crown prince, a feud was caused with the Daikaku ji line.
sen.cmt: “it caused a feud with the Daikaku”=> “a feud was caused with the Daikaku”

sen.j: 1290年には宮中に浅原為頼の一族が押し入る天皇暗殺未遂事件が起きる。
sen.e: In 1290, there was an assassination attempt to kill the Emperor and Tameyori ASAHARA forced to enter to the Imperial Palace.
In 1290 there was an attempt to assassinate the Emperor, and Tameyori ASAHARA was forced to enter the Imperial Palace.
In 1290, Tameyori ASAHARA forced his way into the Imperial Palace and attempted to assassinate the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 「宮中に浅原為頼の一族が押し入る」の部分の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: この事件は初め、北条氏による弘安合戦により所領を没収された事による反抗かと思われたが、後に三条実盛の関与が発覚し、亀山上皇が裏で策動していたと言う疑惑があった。
sen.e: This incident initially was presumed that HOJO family (clan) made a countercharge since their private land was taken away in the Battle of Koan, however it was found out later on that Sanemori SANJO was involved in, there was a suspicion ex-Emperor KAMEYAMA agitated the matter behind the scenes.

In regard to this incident it was initially presumed that HOJO family (clan) made a countercharge, since their private land had been taken away in the Battle of Koan; however, it was subsequently discovered that Sanemori SANJO was involved, and there was suspicion that the ex-emperor Kameyama had agitated the matter behind the scenes.

In regard to this incident it was initially presumed that Hojo clan made a countercharge, since their private land had been taken away in the Battle of Koan; however, it was subsequently discovered that Sanemori SANJO was involved, and there was suspicion that the retired Emperor Kameyama had agitated the matter behind the scenes.

sen.j: 治世中門閥貴族による政治の打破などに力を入れるが、鎌倉幕府の干渉が強まると1298年、後伏見天皇に譲位して院政を執り行った。
sen.e: While his reign, he tried to control court nobles to abolish the politics, after the Kamakura shogunate [bakufu, government] started getting involved into the politics, he passed the throne to Emperor GO-FUSHIMI and started ruling the cloister government.
sen.cmt: 鎌倉幕府→the Kamakura shogunate [bakufu, government]
sen.e: During his reign he tried to control the court nobles in order to abolish the politics; and after the Kamakura shogunate [bakufu, government] started getting involved in politics, he passed the throne to Emperor Go-Fushimi and started ruling the cloister government.

During his reign he tried to control the court nobles in order to abolish the politics; and after the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) started getting involved in politics, he passed the throne to Emperor Gofushimi in 1298 and started ruling the cloister government.
sen.cmt: Kamakura shogunate [bakufu, government]→Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)Go-Fushimi→Gofushimiin 1298 補足

sen.j: しかし、3年後の1301年には、大覚寺統の巻き返しにより後二条天皇に譲位している。
sen.e: However after three years, in 1301, Daikaku ji line took back the political control and Emperor GO-NIJO succeeded to the throne.
However, after three years (in 1301) the Daikaku ji line took back the political control and Emperor Go-Nijo succeeded to the throne.
However, after three years (in 1301) the Daikaku ji line took back the political control and Emperor Gonijo succeeded to the throne.

sen.j: 1308年に幕府への工作が成功し、第四皇子・花園天皇の即位を実現させ、再び院政を敷いた。
sen.e: In 1308, the work for the Kamakura shogunate [bakufu, government] proved effective and the 4th Prince enthroned as Emperor HANAZONO in 1308, Emperor FUSHIMI again ruled the cloister government.

In 1308, the work for the Kamakura shogunate [bakufu, government] proved effective and the fourth prince was enthroned as Emperor Hanazono in 1308, so that Emperor Fushimi again ruled the cloister government.

In 1308, the political maneuverings of the emperor against the Kamakura bakufu proved successful and the fourth prince was enthroned as Emperor Hanazono, with Emperor Fushimi resuming cloistered rule.
sen.cmt: shogunate [bakufu, government]→bakufu文中のin 1308削除「幕府への工作が成功し」の部分の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 伏見天皇の時代は、持明院統と大覚寺統が解決策を見つけられず綱引きをしていた時代である。
sen.e: While Emperor FUSHIMI' reign, Daimyo ji line and Daikaku ji line could not come to the agreement, they were maintaining their political power on a tightrope.
During the reign of Emperor Fushimi, the Daimyo ji and Daikaku ji lines could not come to an agreement and therefore wielded their political power on a tightrope.
During the reign of Emperor Fushimi, there was a dispute over who wielded political power as the Jimyo-in and Daikaku-ji lines were unable to come to an agreement.
sen.cmt: Daimyo→Jimyo in 「綱引きをしていた」の部分の表現を修正しました。

sen.e: The Emperor died in 1317.
The Emperor died in 1317.
The Emperor died in 1317.

sen.j: 伏見天皇の政治は皮肉にも政敵である亀山上皇の政策を踏襲したものであり、朝廷における訴訟機構の刷新や記録荘園券契所の充実などにより政治的権威の回復に積極的に取り組んだ。
sen.e: Emperor FUSHIMI's politic ironically followed his opposition, ex-Emperor KAMEYAMA, he worked actively to restore the authority of Imperial Palace, by reforming court institution of the Palace or to establish Kiroku Shoen Ken kei sho.
sen.cmt: 記録荘園券契所→Kiroku Shoen Ken kei sho [定訳不明、平安中期に荘園の乱立をおさえるために設けられた役所。]
sen.e: Emperor Fushimi's politic ironically followed his opposition, the ex-emperor Kameyama; he worked actively to restore the authority of the Imperial Palace by reforming the court institution of the palace or establishing Kiroku Shoen Ken kei sho.

Emperor Fushimi's politic ironically followed his opposition, the retired Emperor Kameyama; he worked actively to restore the authority of the Imperial Palace by reforming the court institution of the palace or establishing Kiroku Shoen Ken kei sho (an office established in the Heian period to prevent having municipa manor)
sen.cmt: ex-emperor→retired EmperorKiroku Shoen Ken kei sho の説明を加えました。

sen.j: また、皇位継承に介入する鎌倉幕府に対して強い不信感を持ち、在世中は倒幕画策の噂が立てられるほどであった。
sen.e: Also he had a strong suspicion towards the Kamakura shogunate [bakufu, government] as they tried to get involved into the succession of the Imperial Throne, while his reign, there was even a rumor that the Emperor had an intention to defeat the Kamakura Shogunate.

He was also strongly suspicious toward the Kamakura shogunate [bakufu, government], which had tried to get involved in the succession of the Imperial Throne; during his reign there was even a rumor that the Emperor had an intention to defeat the Kamakura shogunate.

He was also strongly suspicious toward the Kamakura bakufu, which had tried to get involved in the succession of the Imperial Throne; during his reign there was even a rumor that the Emperor had an intention to defeat the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: このため、天皇の和歌の師で一番の側近であった京極為兼が二度も流刑となっているのは、天皇が反幕府的な動きを取った事に対する見せしめではないかという説も唱えられている。
sen.e: Thus there is a theory the reason the Emperor's poet teacher and his closest aides, Tamekane KYOGOKU being sentenced to deportation was because the Emperor acted to be against the Kamakura Shogunate and Tamekane was set an example.

Thus there is a theory that the reason the Emperor's poet teacher and closest aide, Tamekane KYOGOKU, was sentenced to deportation was because the Emperor had acted against the Kamakura shogunate so that Tamekane was set forth as an example.

Thus there is a theory that the reason the Emperor's poet teacher and closest aide, Tamekane KYOGOKU, was exiled twice was because the Kamakura bakufu wanted to send a warning to the Emperor in response to his actions against them.
sen.cmt: twice訳抜け補足Kamakura shogunate [bakufu, government]→Kamakura bakufu 「天皇が反幕府的な動きを取った事に対する見せしめではないかという説も唱えられている。」の部分をわかりやすく訳し直しました。

sen.e: Koan (October 21st, 1287) - April 28th, 1288
Koan (October 21, 1287) - April 28, 1288
Koan (October 21, 1287) - April 28, 1288
Sho-ou April 28th, 1288 - August 5th, 1293
Sho-ou April 28, 1288 - August 5, 1293
Shoo April 28, 1288 - August 5, 1293
Einin August 5th, 1293 - (July 22nd, 1298)
Einin August 5, 1293 - (July 22, 1298)
Einin August 5, 1293 - (July 22, 1298)

sen.j: 退位後長く住んだ洛南の離宮伏見殿にちなみ、伏見院と追号。
sen.e: He received a posthumous name, Fuhsimi in, the name came from the Palace he lived for long time in Rakunan, after the abdication.
He received a posthumous name, Fushimi in, the name came from the Palace he lived for long time in Rakunan, after the abdication.
He received a posthumous name, Fushimi in, the name came from the Palace he lived for long time in Rakunan, after the abdication.

sen.j: また、持明院統代々の仙洞御所であり伏見天皇崩御の場でもある持明院殿とも称された。
sen.e: Also he was called Jumyo in dono, the name of the successive Sento (Palace for a retired emperor) Imperial Palace of Jumyo in line, and also the name where Emperor FUSHIMI died.

Additionally, he was called Jumyo in dono, the name of the successive sento (the palace for a retired emperor) Imperial Palace of Jumyo in line, and also the name of the place where Emperor Fushimi died.

Additionally, he was called Jimyo in dono, the name of the successive sento (the palace for a retired emperor) Imperial Palace of Jimyo in line, and also the name of the place where Emperor Fushimi died.

sen.j: 京都市伏見区深草坊町の深草十二帝陵こと深草北陵（ふかくさきたのみささぎ）に持明院統歴代とともに葬られた。
sen.e: The Emperor was entombed with successive Emperors of Jumyo in to in Fukakusa kita no misasagi or also called as Fukakusa ju-ni tei ryo, Fukakusa bo-cho Town, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.
The Emperor was entombed with successive Emperors of Jumyo in to in Fukakusa kita no misasagi or also called as Fukakusa ju-ni tei ryo, Fukakusa bo-cho Town, in the Fushimi ward of Kyoto City.
The Emperor was entombed with successive Emperors of Jimyo in to in Fukakusa kita no misasagi or also called as Fukakusa ju-ni tei ryo, Fukakusa bo-cho Town, in the Fushimi Ward of Kyoto City.
